doc.body:
Makes this work in IE and jsdom. see #5

Tests passing aside from the spec already corrected in #3
doc.content:
Makes this work in IE and jsdom. see #5

Tests passing aside from the spec already corrected in #3

doc.title: EventTarget assumed to be in window
doc.body:
It is of my understanding of the spec that there's no implication that `EventTarget` will be available on `window`. While major browsers appear to expose it I imagine there are DOM implementations that do not (jsdom being one for sure - it causes an error). 
So I propose patching methods in `Node.prototype` instead of `EventTarget.prototype`.
doc.content:
It is of my understanding of the spec that there's no implication that `EventTarget` will be available on `window`. While major browsers appear to expose it I imagine there are DOM implementations that do not (jsdom being one for sure - it causes an error). 
So I propose patching methods in `Node.prototype` instead of `EventTarget.prototype`.

comments.author: btford

doc.body: I noticed that one test fails, and it appears that line 31 in long-stack-trace-zone.spec.js should be `expect(log[1].split('--- ').length).toBe(4);`, and not `expect(log[1].split('--- ').length).toBe(3);`, due to the first element being the stack trace constructed by `Zone.Stacktrace.prototype.get`, and one element for each level of nesting in the async chain run via `lstz.run`.
doc.content: I noticed that one test fails, and it appears that line 31 in long-stack-trace-zone.spec.js should be `expect(log[1].split('--- ').length).toBe(4);`, and not `expect(log[1].split('--- ').length).toBe(3);`, due to the first element being the stack trace constructed by `Zone.Stacktrace.prototype.get`, and one element for each level of nesting in the async chain run via `lstz.run`.

doc.title: window.onerror

comments.body: Thanks @blittle! I'll have to do some research, but it might be possible.
comments.content: Thanks @blittle! I'll have to do some research, but it might be possible.
comments.author: btford

doc.body:
Chrome recently landed an awesome new feature where an actual error object is passed to `window.onerror`. Without an actual error object, it is really difficult make use of the `window.onerror` because the original context is lost and no stack trace is available. Even libraries like stacktrace.js are unable to work around this.

Any idea if zone.js is able to work around this for IE and FF? 

References:
https://code.google.com/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=147127
https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=355430
https://github.com/stacktracejs/stacktrace.js/issues/26
doc.content:
Chrome recently landed an awesome new feature where an actual error object is passed to `window.onerror`. Without an actual error object, it is really difficult make use of the `window.onerror` because the original context is lost and no stack trace is available. Even libraries like stacktrace.js are unable to work around this.

Any idea if zone.js is able to work around this for IE and FF? 

References:
https://code.google.com/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=147127
https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=355430
https://github.com/stacktracejs/stacktrace.js/issues/26
